text: ooh hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
Sturgill Simpson album sound and fury
this is the newest album from country
renegade Sturgill Simpson it comes
several years after his fantastic and
widely acclaimed a sailor's guide to
earth a great contribution to the modern
country catalog fusing the genre with
elements of rock elements of soul with
some very grand and vast production
occasionally some progressive
compositional transitions Simpson is
essentially a country artist who has the
potential to do things in the genre that
are left field that are outside of the
norm that are ground breaking while
simultaneously appealing to the core
audience of that genre which is rare and
because of that I have very much been
looking forward to whatever his next
record is going to be so here we have it
sound and fury several years later but
it comes after a turbulent series of
events first we have Simpsons 2017
Grammy win for a country album of the
year then a sinus infection so bad it
required surgery leading to a lengthy
recovery process that I'm reading
Simpson mostly spent hi out of his mind
he spent much of this downtime listening
to old favorites outside of the country
genre so eventually when he reconvened
with the band they were ready to do even
more unlikely fusions with the style
sound and fury was also recorded in two
weeks and comes along with a companion
film on Netflix that Simpson wrote and
produced along with the founder of a
Tokyo animation studio kamikaze Doga the
whole thing is about a post-apocalyptic
Samurai so it kind of goes without
saying that Simpson is coming from a
somewhat weird place on this one and
sure at its core it doesn't sound like
Simpson has changed his songwriting
style too much many of these tracks as
out there as they can be do have a
distinct country twang to them but
Simpson and his band are dressing these
country tunes in tons of compression
tons of overdrive hardrock guitars
disco rhythms
vintage semi futuristic synthesizers all
you have to do is hear a few seconds of
the sci-fi synth leads and the chunky
rhythms and the mind-numbing to know
guitar leads on best clockmaker on Mars
to hear that we are not in Kansas
anymore look I'm not going to beat
around the bush on this one these tracks
are pretty experimental for Simpson any
major relevant country artist working
today really some of these experiments
sound fantastic and others go so awry
they make for Simpsons worst material to
date for one I love the tracks
sing-along which was great as a teaser
even better as a poor song on the record
fat drums on this track are fantastic
the funky gurgly keyboard licks the
whaling slide guitars too it's got a
great groove I love Simpsons totally
buzzing fuzz doubt lead vocal on this
one the song sounds like an old friend
but also like an alien from another
planet
the screaming synth leads on the bridge
of this cut are nice - it's like I'm
listening to dystopian cyber country I
also love the track good look which is
backed with these very fast peppy groovy
disco beats that bassline that hip
shaking beat those bright fluttery
layers of strings on the track they all
sound like something straight out of
1975 and the way the whole instrumental
transitions into this loud laser synth
breakdown is crazy when the instrumental
clears on the verse a very solid tune is
revealed as well as some smart and
snappy lyrics about the end of the world
Fame copyrights the song Ronan isn't the
bad instrumental kickoff to this thing
even though I think it does drag on a
bit too long it's a little too impressed
with its own lumbering rhythms and
somewhat bland guitar passages remember
to breathe there's also a track that I
think contributes to the first leg of
this album being incredibly solid
however once you hit the midpoint of
this thing I think the quality begins to
take a nosedive for one I cannot stand
make art not friends it takes way too
long
to get started and when it eventually
gets there it's this slow lumbering
awkward patience testing song you
couldn't have up to the tempo on this
one a little bit just just a smidge at
this pace this track sounds like a bad
Gary
Numan song or at least like the band is
is trying to perform in quicksand
already voiced my annoyances with best
clock maker on Mars those two note
guitar riffs are awful all said and done
is a very sweet mellow melodic oasis in
the second leg of this record but it's
still not a highlight for me meanwhile
the production on Last Man Standing is
trash it just sounds like a really bad
live recording with the guitars blaring
to the point where they're smothering
everything the drums sound like they're
being played at a distance the vocals
are muffled and and just really
unintelligible much of the time so even
if the song at the core of this one is
one of the bettors of this entire
project you you wouldn't really be able
to tell from just how not good it sounds
some of the new wave elements that were
very lightly referenced earlier on the
record come back on mercury in
retrograde where it sounds like we have
some nice punchy drums some lightly
phased and gently strum guitars
it's plucky it's pretty sounds a little
intergalactic when you get that
wonderful rush of instrumentation on the
chorus there are some parts of it that
remind me of the cars then we have the
fastest horse in town the longest track
on the entire record and it is so
goddamn loud especially the guitars it
just gets more and more distorted the
whole thing is like an asteroid burning
up in Earth's atmosphere look there are
some elements of this album that I
admire that I think are risky that I
think are very cool and there are others
that again I don't think compliment
Simpson all that much I don't think go
over that well I think frankly sound
awful
I like that Simpson and his band really
let loose on this one but a lot of
terrible ideas and sounds go completely
unchecked and there are really enough of
them to make this record a very spotty
inconsistent listen I'm feeling a decent
two strong five on this one transition
